awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:   INTEGRATING FOSSIL AND MODERN EVIDENCE TO DETERMINE THE ROLE OF DIET IN MAMMALIAN DIVERSIFICATION
awd_abstract_narration:
Mammals have evolved diverse diets to fuel their demanding metabolisms. This study will investigate the role diet played in mammalian diversification by combining data from the fossil record with data on living mammals. Work will focus on three groups with good fossil records and variable diets:  Primates, Carnivora (e.g. dogs, cats and bears), and Cetartiodactyla (e.g. deer, cows and whales). A combination of morphological and DNA data will be used to produce a time-calibrated phylogeny of each group that includes fossil and living species. These phylogenetic trees will then be analyzed with dietary data to estimate speciation and extinction rates in mammals with different diets. The results will be compared to traditional paleontological methods to quantify the biases of these different approaches in reconstructing diversification history.

This study of mammalian dietary evolution will elucidate the evolutionary role diet played in the origin of living mammals, including humans, and whether the evolutionary trajectory of omnivory in our ancestors paralleled its origin in other primates. It will also contribute to consilience between paleontological and phylogenetic approaches to macroevolutionary biology, facilitating interdisciplinary collaboration. The project will support training of undergraduate and graduate students along with the development of K-16 educational materials.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of our original proposal was determine how differences in mammalian diversification are influenced by diet, do omnivores have the lowest net diversification rates because they have low speciation rates or high extinction rates? To do this we needed to focus on a few groups: Carnivora (cats, dogs & bears), Cetartiodactyla (deer, goats, pigs) and Primates (apes, tamarins & lemurs), which we believed would have enough data available to enable us to identify the diet of fossil for several mammalian lineages and analyze both fossil and modern diversity in a unified phylogenetic framework built from DNA and morphological data. As there are hundreds to thousands of species in each group when you include fossils, we had to use existing morphological data, so we found and extracted into a usable format all available morphological character matrices (171 in total). However, we discovered that the lack of overlap between morphological characters and the fact that less than 30% of fossil species have been included in any matrix, precluded the generation of a combined morphological and DNA phylogeny.


To identify the diet of fossil species you have to use measurements of skeletal elements that preserve in the fossil record: mammalian teeth are numerous in the fossil record and should reflect what the animal has been eating. To ascertain the best way to infer diet from teeth for our hundreds of fossil species we tested ten different measurements and ratios that had been used previously in the scientific literature, starting with Carnivora as they were the best studied. To our surprise our analyses revealed that ecological signal within the teeth was confounded by the phylogenetic signal and once that was taken into account tooth measurements poorly predicted the known diets of living species. Tooth shape varies much more than can be captured by simple metrics, so we decided to use a technique known as geometric morphometrics to capture the overall shape of the carnassial teeth and the position of the well-established primary cusps, which are known to be formed by the same developmental processes in all mammals. Carnassial teeth are the defining feature of carnivorans and are frequently used to infer diet, however our work confirmed that these data were also confounded by phylogenetic signal. We were therefore unable to identify a quantitative method to reliably estimate diet from teeth across Carnivora, especially for fossil species outside living groups. Intriguingly, when studying the position of the primary cusps of the carnivoran teeth we were able to identify a previously unknown pattern. Specifically, living cats and their relatives (feliforms) and dogs and their relatives (caniforms) had very different ways of extending the shearing blades for slicing through flesh. We therefore decided to investigate this pattern further, to see how the tooth morphology changed over time and whether ancestral carnivorans had cat-like or dog-like carnassial cusp placement or something else entirely. We collected carnassial shape data on additional 200+ fossil species, covering most major groups. Our analyses of the fossil teeth indicate that the differences seen between living feliforms and caniforms deteriorate rapidly in the fossil record, and point to modern cats as having novel morphologies that drive the patterns in extant feliforms. This highlights the difficulty of sometimes using modern species to identify morphological proxies for ecology for use within more distantly related fossils.


We conclude, while it is imperative to include fossil diversity into analyses of diversification, it is currently impossible to do so using best-practices at the macroevolutionary scale. Our work reveals that even the best-studied groups lack existing morphological data to permit the building of comprehensive fossil and living phylogenies using molecular and morphological data. Unfortunately, generating the morphological data for thousands of species from scratch is currently prohibitively time-consuming and expensive. Our findings also highlight the critical importance of routinely testing, even generally accepted, relationships between morphology and ecology and identifying the appropriate taxonomic-level for their application before using them to infer the ecology of fossil organisms. We have disseminated these conclusions to geologists and biologists at professional meetings across the US and internationally. We have also explained our findings to high school teachers and students, as well as the general public. In total, we have trained three graduate and five undergraduate students in integrative evolutionary analyses, teaching them to use rigorous quantitative phylogenetic and paleontological methods. They have experienced first-hand the need for, and the challenges associated with, integrating these two approaches. Finally, working with high-school teachers we have developed a unit on evolution for high school biology using our findings and with reference to the Next Generation Science Standards that will be made available online.
